address.text: King Abdulaziz District, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia

reasonCode.text: Excessive thirst, frequent urination, and unexplained weight loss for 2 weeks

resource.valueString: Patient appears well but tired. Mucous membranes dry suggesting mild dehydration.
No diabetic foot ulcers. Monofilament test normal.

text.div: Excessive thirst, frequent urination, and unexplained weight loss for 2 weeks

60-year-old Saudi male businessman presents with classic symptoms of diabetes. Reports drinking 4-5 liters of water daily, urinating every hour including nighttime (nocturia 6-8 times). Lost 8kg over 2 weeks despite normal appetite. Also reports fatigue and blurred vision. Onset: 2 weeks ago. Quality: Polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss. Severity: Significant impact on daily activities. Associated symptoms: Fatigue, blurred vision.

Medical Conditions:

  • No significant past medical history
  • No previous hospitalizations

Surgical History:

  • None
Endocrine: Polyuria, polydipsia, weight loss, fatigue. Cardiovascular: No chest pain. Neurological: Blurred vision. Genitourinary: Nocturia. Constitutional: Fatigue, weight loss.
No current medications prior to this visit.
Smoking: Former smoker. Alcohol: Occasional. Exercise: Sedentary lifestyle due to desk job. Occupation: Businessman. Diet: Traditional Saudi meals, high carbohydrate intake.

Strong family history of diabetes mellitus. Father diagnosed with Type 2 DM at age 55, managed with oral medications until his death at 78 from cardiovascular complications. Elder brother (62 years) has Type 2 DM diagnosed 5 years ago, well-controlled with metformin. Younger brother (54 years) recently diagnosed with Type 2 DM. Mother (85 years) has hypertension and osteoporosis, no diabetes.

Vital Signs:

  • BP: 145/90 mmHg
  • HR: 88 bpm
  • Weight: 88kg
  • Height: 172cm
  • BMI: 29.7

Physical Examination:

  • General: Patient appears well but tired. Mucous membranes dry suggesting mild dehydration.
  • Fundoscopic: Early diabetic changes
  • Foot Exam: No diabetic foot ulcers. Monofilament test normal.

Lab Results:

  • Random glucose: 285 mg/dL (High)
  • HbA1c: 11.2% (Poor glycemic control)

New diagnosis of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus with poor glycemic control (HbA1c 11.2%). Mild hypertension likely related to diabetes. Risk factors include strong family history, obesity (BMI 29.7), sedentary lifestyle, and traditional high-carbohydrate diet. Early diabetic retinal changes noted on fundoscopy. No evidence of diabetic foot complications at this time. Requires immediate glycemic control and comprehensive diabetes education.

1. Start Metformin 500mg BID 2. Diabetes education and dietary counseling 3. Blood glucose monitoring 4. Lifestyle modifications - increase physical activity 5. Ophthalmology referral 6. Follow-up in 2 weeks 7. Annual diabetic screening labs 8. Consider ACE inhibitor for BP control

Patient counseled on diabetes diagnosis, importance of medication compliance, dietary modifications, and lifestyle changes. Emphasized need for regular monitoring and follow-up. Family education provided regarding diabetes management. Patient expressed understanding and willingness to make necessary lifestyle changes.

note.text: Repeat in 4 weeks to assess response to metformin therapy
Fasting lipid profile for cardiovascular risk assessment
Diabetic retinal screening and management of early diabetic changes
Comprehensive diabetes self-management education including diet, exercise, glucose monitoring, and medication compliance

resource.description: Diabetes follow-up visit - assess response to metformin, review glucose logs, adjust treatment plan
